00263 #if CONFIG_KERN_PREEMPT
00264 
00282     INLINE void proc_forbid(void)
00283     {
00284         extern cpu_atomic_t preempt_count;
00285         /*
00286          * We don't need to protect the counter against other processes.
00287          * The reason why is a bit subtle.
00288          *
00289          * If a process gets here, preempt_forbid_cnt can be either 0,
00290          * or != 0.  In the latter case, preemption is already disabled
00291          * and no concurrency issues can occur.
00292          *
00293          * In the former case, we could be preempted just after reading the
00294          * value 0 from memory, and a concurrent process might, in fact,
00295          * bump the value of preempt_forbid_cnt under our nose!
00296          *
00297          * BUT: if this ever happens, then we won't get another chance to
00298          * run until the other process calls proc_permit() to re-enable
00299          * preemption.  At this point, the value of preempt_forbid_cnt
00300          * must be back to 0, and thus what we had originally read from
00301          * memory happens to be valid.
00302          *
00303          * No matter how hard you think about it, and how complicated you
00304          * make your scenario, the above holds true as long as
00305          * "preempt_forbid_cnt != 0" means that no task switching is
00306          * possible.
00307          */
00308         ++preempt_count;
00309 
00310         /*
00311          * Make sure preempt_count is flushed to memory so the preemption
00312          * softirq will see the correct value from now on.
00313          */
00314         MEMORY_BARRIER;
00315     }
00316 
00322     INLINE void proc_permit(void)
00323     {
00324         extern cpu_atomic_t preempt_count;
00325 
00326         /*
00327          * This is to ensure any global state changed by the process gets
00328          * flushed to memory before task switching is re-enabled.
00329          */
00330         MEMORY_BARRIER;
00331         /* No need to protect against interrupts here. */
00332         ASSERT(preempt_count > 0);
00333         --preempt_count;
00334         /*
00335          * This ensures preempt_count is flushed to memory immediately so the
00336          * preemption interrupt sees the correct value.
00337          */
00338         MEMORY_BARRIER;
00339     }
00340 
00346     INLINE bool proc_preemptAllowed(void)
00347     {
00348         extern cpu_atomic_t preempt_count;
00349         return (preempt_count == 0);
00350     }
00351 #else /* CONFIG_KERN_PREEMPT */
00352     #define proc_forbid() /* NOP */
00353     #define proc_permit() /* NOP */
00354     #define proc_preemptAllowed() (true)
00355 #endif /* CONFIG_KERN_PREEMPT */
00356 
00358 #define proc_allowed() proc_preemptAllowed()
00359 
00363 #define PROC_ATOMIC(CODE) \
00364     do { \
00365         proc_forbid(); \
00366         CODE; \
00367         proc_permit(); \
00368     } while(0)
00369 
00388 #if (ARCH & ARCH_EMUL)
00389     /* We need a large stack because system libraries are bloated */
00390     #define KERN_MINSTACKSIZE 65536
00391 #else
00392     #if CONFIG_KERN_PREEMPT
00393         /*
00394          * A preemptible kernel needs a larger stack compared to the
00395          * cooperative case. A task can be interrupted anytime in each
00396          * node of the call graph, at any level of depth. This may
00397          * result in a higher stack consumption, to call the ISR, save
00398          * the current user context and to execute the kernel
00399          * preemption routines implemented as ISR prologue and
00400          * epilogue. All these calls are nested into the process stack.
00401          *
00402          * So, to reduce the risk of stack overflow/underflow problems
00403          * add a x2 to the portion stack reserved to the user process.
00404          */
00405         #define KERN_MINSTACKSIZE \
00406             (sizeof(Process) + CPU_SAVED_REGS_CNT * 2 * sizeof(cpu_stack_t) \
00407             + 32 * sizeof(int) * 2)
00408     #else
00409         #define KERN_MINSTACKSIZE \
00410             (sizeof(Process) + CPU_SAVED_REGS_CNT * 2 * sizeof(cpu_stack_t) \
00411             + 32 * sizeof(int))
00412     #endif /* CONFIG_KERN_PREEMPT */
00413 
00414 #endif
00415 
00416 #ifndef CONFIG_KERN_MINSTACKSIZE
00417     /* For backward compatibility */
00418     #define CONFIG_KERN_MINSTACKSIZE KERN_MINSTACKSIZE
00419 #else
00420     #warning FIXME: This macro is deprecated, use KERN_MINSTACKSIZE instead
00421 #endif
00422 
00434 #define PROC_DEFINE_STACK(name, size) \
00435     cpu_stack_t name[((size) + sizeof(cpu_stack_t) - 1) / sizeof(cpu_stack_t)]; \
00436     STATIC_ASSERT((size) >= KERN_MINSTACKSIZE);
00437 
00438 /* Memory fill codes to help debugging */
00439 #if CONFIG_KERN_MONITOR
00440     #include <cpu/types.h>
00441     #if (SIZEOF_CPUSTACK_T == 1)
00442         /* 8bit cpu_stack_t */
00443         #define CONFIG_KERN_STACKFILLCODE  0xA5
00444         #define CONFIG_KERN_MEMFILLCODE    0xDB
00445     #elif (SIZEOF_CPUSTACK_T == 2)
00446         /* 16bit cpu_stack_t */
00447         #define CONFIG_KERN_STACKFILLCODE  0xA5A5
00448         #define CONFIG_KERN_MEMFILLCODE    0xDBDB
00449     #elif (SIZEOF_CPUSTACK_T == 4)
00450         /* 32bit cpu_stack_t */
00451         #define CONFIG_KERN_STACKFILLCODE  0xA5A5A5A5UL
00452         #define CONFIG_KERN_MEMFILLCODE    0xDBDBDBDBUL
00453     #elif (SIZEOF_CPUSTACK_T == 8)
00454         /* 64bit cpu_stack_t */
00455         #define CONFIG_KERN_STACKFILLCODE  0xA5A5A5A5A5A5A5A5ULL
00456         #define CONFIG_KERN_MEMFILLCODE    0xDBDBDBDBDBDBDBDBULL
00457     #else
00458         #error No cpu_stack_t size supported!
00459     #endif
00460 #endif
